perturbation.original_text: PFHOF shall, within fourteen (14) days of its receipt of the recommendation of the Advisory Board, either approve or reject the proposal as set forth in the Notice. If PFHOF does not approve the proposal as set forth in the Notice within fourteen (14) days of PFHOF’s receipt of the recommendation of the Advisory Board, such proposal shall be deemed rejected by PFHOF.
perturbation.changed_text: PFHOF shall, within seventy (70) days of its receipt of the recommendation of the Advisory Board, either approve or reject the proposal as set forth in the Notice. If PFHOF does not approve the proposal as set forth in the Notice within seventy (70) days of PFHOF’s receipt of the recommendation of the Advisory Board, such proposal shall be deemed rejected by PFHOF.
perturbation.explanation: The modification extends the approval/rejection period for PFHOF's decision regarding the Village Media Company's proposal from 14 days to 70 days. Ohio law (and general contract law principles) require timely decisions to avoid hindering business operations. Excessively delaying approval process may constitute a breach of good faith and fair dealing, and unjust enrichment.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Ohio contract law - Breach of Good Faith and Fair Dealing and unjust enrichment.

perturbation.original_text: Thereafter, the agreement shall automatically renew for successive five (5)-year terms, unless either Party gives written notice to the other Party of intent not to renew at least six (6) months prior to the expiration of the then-current Term.
perturbation.changed_text: Thereafter, the agreement shall automatically renew for successive five (5)-year terms, unless either Party gives written notice to the other Party of intent not to renew at least one (1) months prior to the expiration of the then-current Term.
perturbation.explanation: The change reduces the notice period required to prevent automatic renewal of the agreement from six months to one month. Ohio law and general contract law necessitate a reasonable notification period for non-renewal to allow the other party adequate time to prepare, especially when a contract entails long-term business relationships and significant financial investments. Shortening the notice period may render the renewal clause unconscionable and unenforceable, especially if the non-renewing party has accrued substantial benefits, which is a case of unjust enrichment.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Ohio contract law - Unconscionability, Adequate Time to Prepare, and Unjust Enrichment.

perturbation.original_text: Confidential Information shall not include such information that: (i) as of the date of disclosure is known to the Receiving Party or its Affiliates, as shown by written documentation; (ii) was independently developed by the Receiving Party or its Affiliates without access to the Disclosing Party’s Confidential Information; (iii) as of the date of disclosure is in, or subsequently enters, the public domain, through no fault of the Receiving Party; or (iv) as of the date of disclosure or thereafter is obtained from a third party free from any obligation of confidentiality to the Disclosing Party.
perturbation.changed_text: Confidential Information shall not include such information that: (i) is known to the Receiving Party or its Affiliates; (ii) was independently developed by the Receiving Party or its Affiliates; (iii) is in, or subsequently enters, the public domain; or (iv) is obtained from a third party.
perturbation.explanation: The modified text removes the requirement for "written documentation" to prove prior knowledge, eliminates the "without access" clause for independently developed information, omits "through no fault of the Receiving Party" from the public domain exception, and takes away the "free from any obligation of confidentiality to the Disclosing Party." Removing these protections weakens the confidentiality clause and could conflict with Ohio's trade secret law, which requires reasonable efforts to maintain secrecy.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Ohio Trade Secrets Act - Reasonable efforts to maintain secrecy.
